name: Inanna
title: Inanna (Ishtar) - Sumerian Mythology
subtitle: Queen of Heaven and Earth
longDescription:
Queen of Heaven and Earth

Inanna is the most important goddess in Sumerian mythology‚Äîthe Queen of Heaven, goddess of love, sexuality, war, political power, and fertility. She is bold, ambitious, and unstoppable. Inanna's myths show her stealing divine powers from Enki, conquering the underworld, and demanding worship from cities. She embodies the paradox of creation and destruction, love and war, life and death.

Inanna's myths are among the most powerful and psychologically complex in ancient literature. She is never passive‚Äîshe acts, demands, conquers, and transforms. Her stories explore desire, power, mortality, and rebirth.

Inanna appears extensively in ancient Sumerian cuneiform texts. Search the ORACC corpus to explore original texts mentioning Inanna in transliteration and translation.

Also known as: Inana (alternate spelling). Major texts include: "Inanna and Enki," "The Descent of Inanna," "Inanna and the Huluppu Tree," hymns to Inanna from Uruk

Uruk was Inanna's primary cult center, where she shared the great temple E-anna ("House of Heaven") with An. Uruk was ancient Mesopotamia's largest and most powerful city. Inanna was also worshipped at Zabalam, Akkad, and eventually throughout the ancient Near East as Ishtar (Akkadian/Babylonian), Astarte (Canaanite), and Aphrodite (Greek).

Precious jewelry and clothing, perfumes and oils, date wine and honey cakes, red dyed textiles, lions (sacrificed or depicted), flowers (especially roses), gold and lapis lazuli. Sacred prostitutes (hierodules) served in her temples, and sexual acts were considered worship. Musicians and dancers performed in her honor, as art and beauty glorified the goddess.

Lovers prayed to Inanna for passion and success in romance. Warriors invoked her for victory in battle‚Äîshe was "she who strides across battlefields." Kings sought her blessing for legitimate authority. Women prayed for fertility and safe childbirth. Hymns praised her contradictory nature: "Lady of all powers, light-giving luminary, Inanna, righteous woman clothed in radiance, beloved of Heaven and Earth."

parents: in some traditions daughter of An
consorts: various mortal kings in sacred marriage rites

worship.sacredSites: Uruk was Inanna's primary cult center, where she shared the great temple E-anna ("House of Heaven") with An. Uruk was ancient Mesopotamia's largest and most powerful city. Inanna was also worshipped at Zabalam, Akkad, and eventually throughout the ancient Near East as Ishtar (Akkadian/Babylonian), Astarte (Canaanite), and Aphrodite (Greek).

festivals.name: Sacred Marriage (Hieros Gamos)
festivals.description: At the New Year festival, the king or high priest ritually married a priestess representing Inanna. This enacted the union of Inanna and Dumuzi, ensuring fertility for the land. The ritual involved processions, offerings, and sacred sexual union in the temple. This legitimized the king's rule and renewed cosmic order.

festivals.name: Descent and Return
festivals.description: Annual mourning ritual commemorating Inanna's death in the underworld followed by celebration of her return. Dumuzi's descent was also mourned‚Äîwomen wept for the dying god. This explained seasonal changes and agricultural cycles.

worship.offerings: Precious jewelry and clothing, perfumes and oils, date wine and honey cakes, red dyed textiles, lions (sacrificed or depicted), flowers (especially roses), gold and lapis lazuli. Sacred prostitutes (hierodules) served in her temples, and sexual acts were considered worship. Musicians and dancers performed in her honor, as art and beauty glorified the goddess.
worship.prayers: Lovers prayed to Inanna for passion and success in romance. Warriors invoked her for victory in battle‚Äîshe was "she who strides across battlefields." Kings sought her blessing for legitimate authority. Women prayed for fertility and safe childbirth. Hymns praised her contradictory nature: "Lady of all powers, light-giving luminary, Inanna, righteous woman clothed in radiance, beloved of Heaven and Earth."

sections.title: Worship & Rituals
sections.content:
Uruk was Inanna's primary cult center, where she shared the great temple E-anna ("House of Heaven") with An. Uruk was ancient Mesopotamia's largest and most powerful city. sources.title: "The Descent of Inanna" (one of the oldest written myths)
"Inanna and Enki: The Transfer of the Arts of Civilization
